title: Bishops Advance Effort That Could Restrict Communion for Biden
summary: U.S. church leaders approve controversial proposal despite warnings from Vatican. U.S. Catholic bishops on Friday agreed to prepare a document that would lay out the conditions under which Catholic politicians who support abortion rights, including President Biden, may be denied Communion.

title: Judge Sides With Florida in Suit Over CDC's Covid-19 Rules for Cruises
summary: Gov. Ron DeSantis fought to restart cruises, says 'CDC has been wrong all along'. A federal judge sided with Florida in its lawsuit over the federal government's cruise-industry restrictions, a move that could ease the path for ships to resume sailing after a 15-month shutdown due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Iranians Vote in Election Amid Talks to Save Nuclear Deal
summary: Resume Subscription. TEHRAN-Iranians voted Friday in a presidential election heavily skewed in favor of hard-liners, as Tehran negotiates the revival of an international nuclear deal that would free the country's economy from crushing U.S. sanctions.

title: U.S. Military Steps Up Its Withdrawal From Middle East
summary: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin told Saudi crown prince of drawdown in June 2 call, officials say. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is sharply reducing the number of U.S. antimissile systems in the Middle East in a major realignment of its military footprint there as it focuses the armed services on challenges from China and Russia, administration officials said.

title: Saving New York City
summary: The Big Apple needs a turnaround-starting with crime control.. There is much ruin in a city, to adapt Adam Smith, and Bill de Blasio has spent eight years trying to prove it. The progressive's tenure as mayor has been a catastrophe for New York City in nearly every way, and the only saving grace is that he's term-limited. The question as Tuesday's primary approaches is whether voters will try to pull the city out of its downward spiral.

title: Climate Policy by Judicial Decree
summary: 'Sue and settle' is back, this time to remake the U.S. economy.. Democrats know they can't banish fossil fuels or impose carbon taxes democratically, so the Biden Administration is preparing a backup plan: use courts to impose the anti-carbon policies by decree.

title: Doctors for Progressive Conformity
summary: The AMA wants to police the speech of dissenting members.. The American Medical Association is a lobby of doctors that's supposed to promote policies that improve public health and medicine. But it seems to be evolving into another arm of progressive politics, like the teachers unions. See the AMA's policy-making meeting this week.

title: Garland's Bolton Reprieve
summary: The DOJ stops its pursuit of the Trump adviser over his book.. Attorney General Merrick Garland has dismayed progressives by rightly maintaining some of the Trump Justice Department's positions in sensitive litigation, including a defamation suit against the former President and an effort to release a memo related to the Mueller investigation.

title: Boy Scouts Near Deal With Largest Victims Group
summary: Youth group is expected to pay out victims through a combination of cash and insurance policies. The Boy Scouts of America are nearing a settlement with lawyers for sex-abuse victims that marks a major step for the youth group's efforts to end the largest bankruptcy case ever filed over childhood abuse, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Man Sentenced to 2½ Years in $150 Million Bank Fraud
summary: Ray Akhavan was convicted in a scheme to trick financial institutions into processing online marijuana sales. A federal judge sentenced a California businessman to 2½ years in federal prison Friday for orchestrating an international scheme that tricked U.S. banks into processing more than $150 million in marijuana-related purchases.

title: The San Francisco Symphony Returns
summary: The orchestra makes a dazzling comeback, thanks to loosened Covid-19 restrictions and an ambitious new music director, Esa-Pekka Salonen..

title: Biden's Red Lines for Russian Hackers
summary: Is the U.S. finally starting to exploit the terminal decadence of Moscow's ex-KGB regime?. No outcome of the Geneva summit was more eye-opening than Joe Biden's claim to have presented Vladimir Putin with a list of 16 categories of U.S. cyber targets that must remain off-limits to attack.

title: Practical Jokes Were My Father's Vice
summary: In 1973 he was the spitting image of Spiro Agnew. But the joke didn't last long.. If my father were around this Father's Day, we'd probably tease him about the Big Prank. The one that worked beautifully for a while-before it fizzled out in ignominy.

title: Companies Struggle to Keep Their Tech Workers From Logging Off
summary: In seller's market for IT talent, CIOs redouble efforts to retain skilled workers. Many information-technology workers in the U.S. are on the hunt for new jobs, seeking a wider array of remote work options, better chances for promotions and bigger paychecks, as Covid-19 restrictions ease and the economy rebounds.

title: Americans Should Know the Story of Abolitionist Cassius Clay
summary: Muhammad Ali's namesake risked his career, wealth and life to promote emancipation.. In an era of racial "reckoning," the U.S. seems determined to obliterate statues and other public honors for those, such as Confederate generals, who fought to preserve slavery and racism. But there is no countervailing effort to remember or honor those who risked everything-career, wealth, prominence and personal safety-to promote emancipation.

title: European Union Lifts Bond-Sale Ban on Banks
summary: JPMorgan, Citigroup and Bank of America among banks cleared to work on future EU bond sales. The European Union lifted the ban against some banks that had been excluded from working on its bond sale earlier in the week.

title: Dow Drops More Than 500 Points
summary: Stocks drop after Fed official James Bullard said he expects the first rate increase in late 2022. U.S. stocks retreated Friday, as traders warily eyed the Federal Reserve for hints of where monetary policy is headed.

title: Juneteenth, Now a Federal Holiday, Puts Companies to Work on a Response
summary: Employers rush to decide whether and how to give paid time off for the first new federal holiday in nearly four decades. When President Biden signed legislation making June 19, or Juneteenth, a new national holiday, he set off a race inside corporations to figure out how to mark it and whether to allocate more paid time off to workers.

title: Delta Covid-19 Variant Likely to Become Dominant in U.S., CDC Director Says
summary: Public-health officials say vaccinations are key to holding virus in check. The highly contagious Delta variant could soon become the dominant strain of coronavirus in the U.S., the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Friday.

title: Avalanche of Options Trades Fuels Market Pullback
summary: One measure of trading activity has reached its second-highest level on record. Heavy options activity is amplifying this week's frantic investor retreat from bets on stronger economic growth.

title: Lucid Living
summary: Symmetry and simplicity prevail in Philip Johnson's Glass House, a getaway home turned architectural museum in New Canaan, Conn.. When architects build for themselves, they're doing more than making a home, or what Le Corbusier called "a machine for living in." Knowingly or not, they're writing an autobiography. Emerson said "an institution is the lengthened shadow of one man." So is a house.

title: 'Cézanne Drawing' Review: Radical With a Pencil
summary: An exhibition at MoMA argues that the foundational painter of modern art produced his most groundbreaking work on paper.. New York

title: Churchill and 'Woke Totalitarianism'
summary: Another statue is vandalized.. It seems that the wokesters who claim that they are "anti-racists" still can't tolerate the memory of a man who defeated history's most murderous racist. The Thursday defacing of a statue in Canada is the latest effort to cancel Hitler's implacable foe.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: In the weeds with Napoleon Bonaparte; the sharp comic fiction of Laurie Colwin; the designer who transformed the modern office; an author's nightmare from Laura Lippman and more.. The conqueror of Europe was also an 'intermittent gardener' to the end. Review by Christoph Irmscher.

title: Biden Marks Covid-19 Milestone of 300 Million Shots With a Warning on Variant
summary: Delta variant will leave unvaccinated 'even more vulnerable,' president says. President Biden said Friday would mark 300 million shots of the Covid-19 vaccine administered in the U.S. in the 150 days since he took office, but warned of a more easily transmissible variant accounting for an increasing number of cases in the U.S.

title: A Real Composer (Saturday Crossword, June 19)
Go Figure (Saturday Cryptic Puzzle, June 19)
'Napoleon' Review: The General's Garden
summary: In the estate he gave his empress, the gardens were lavish. His life ended in a modest one he tilled himself.. On June 25, 1815, Napoleon Bonaparte arrived at Malmaison, the late Empress Joséphine's estate 7 miles west of Paris. His dream of holding on to the French throne had just shattered at Waterloo, costing the lives of tens of thousands. Five years earlier, he had divorced Joséphine because she hadn't given him the heir his dynastic desires required. Now that she was dead, all he could think about was how much he missed her-how she used to walk under the trees she had planted, those cedars, cypresses and Japanese pagodas, how she would examine the flowers in her greenhouse or gather the roses she loved so much. The memory made Napoleon wince. "She was the most graceful woman I ever saw," he told his stepdaughter Hortense. Too little, too late.

title: Laurie Colwin: The Smile and the Blade
summary: Laurie Colwin applied her comic imagination to big subjects like love and longing.. To be binary about it, there are two kinds of readers in the world. The first-in answer to the question, "Have you ever read Laurie Colwin?"-say, "No." The other kind ignite like a gas jet and sigh, "Ohhhhh. Laurie Colwin."

title: Politics: Nationalism, Then and Now
summary: To decide whether nationalism is good or bad for America, we first have to agree about what it is.. On election night in 2016, the intellectual classes of Europe and North America were ready to turn out books and think pieces on the inexorable advance of transnational progressivism. Instead they were obliged to write about a reinvigorated nationalism, and they were ill-prepared for it. I don't know how many times over the past five years I've read breezy discussions of post-'16 politics that simply assumed racial bigotry and police-state thuggery to be necessary components of any sort of nationalism.

title: Investors Look Beyond the Pitchbook to Assess Managers
summary: Backers of private investment funds use personality tests, Uber scores and genealogy sites for insights into the professional character of investment professionals. Jonathan Harris, wants to know an investment manager's personality before his firm gives them its money.

title: Palestinians Scrap Vaccine Swap With Israel
summary: Palestinian Authority says the soon-to-expire vaccines didn't meet agreed-upon standards. TEL AVIV-The Palestinian Authority on Friday pulled out of a swap of Pfizer -BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine with Israel, citing concerns about the quality of an initial shipment.

title: Fed's Bullard Pencils In Rate Increase in 2022
summary: St. Louis Fed President questions continued mortgage-bond purchases amid robust housing market. Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard said the economy is seeing more inflation than he and his Federal Reserve colleagues anticipated only a few months ago, and that he now expects to see a central bank rate increase next year.

title: 'Fox and I' Review: Something Wild
summary: The barrier between humans and wild animals has a long history, but trust a fox to sneak through.. Earlier this year, the Academy Award for best documentary feature went to "My Octopus Teacher," which chronicled what filmmaker Craig Foster learned from his daily visits to an octopus off the coast of South Africa.

title: Art, Power and Glory in Florence
summary: A new exhibition shows how the ruling Medici family used artworks as propaganda in the 16h century.. A bronze bust of Duke Cosimo I de' Medici reigns over the first part of "The Medici: Portraits and Politics, 1512-1570," a new exhibition opening June 26 at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art. As befits a member of the family that dominated Florence's culture and politics for centuries, the bust by Benvenuto Cellini is larger than life, showing the duke with an "almost frightening expression on his face," says curator Keith Christiansen, who organized the exhibition.

title: How to Ask for a Raise, and Get One
summary: Most Popular News. You have gone above and beyond at work and believe it is time to ask for a raise. But when it comes to increasing your salary, doing good work is just the beginning. Many other elements need to come together to make your request for a raise a certainty. In his book "Empowering Yourself: The Organizational Game Revealed," author Harvey Coleman, who has consulted managers in Fortune 500 companies, lays out three key elements that determine your upward mobility at work: performance, image and exposure. Of those three, he estimates that job performance only amounts to 10% of the equation, while image accounts for 30% and exposure-the amount that people are aware of who you are and what your contributions and value have been-is 60%. "That to me changed the game as far as my career goes," says Madeline Mann, an HR recruiter who has coached clients who have accepted jobs at Google, Netflix, Deloitte and other known companies.

title: What Emerson Can Teach Us About Resilience
summary: The great writer coped with pain and loss by getting back to work, not by withdrawing into 'self-care.'. Since the 19th century, Americans have looked to Ralph Waldo Emerson for wisdom on many subjects, from education to religion to politics. Today, surrounded by political storms and the sorrow and wreckage of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Emerson we need most is the prophet of resilience. Emerson's ideas about resilience stand in potent contrast to our current cultural consensus on how to deal with suffering and loss. Instead of "self-care" and "healing," he offers an aggressive affirmation of the will and of work.

title: AstraZeneca Escapes Fines in Covid-19 Vaccine Lawsuit With EU
summary: Brussels court ruling stems from EU accusations over delays of vaccines the company developed with Oxford University. A Brussels court ruled that AstraZeneca PLC isn't required to accelerate deliveries of its Covid-19 vaccine to the European Union and isn't on the hook for big fines the bloc had sought to impose in a lawsuit over delivery delays.

title: These States Lead the Way on Pension Reform
summary: Arizona, Michigan and Texas are showing how to create resilient systems for government retirees.. State and municipal debt has tripled since 2000, with unfunded public pension liabilities mostly to blame. After 20 years of inadequate funding policies, failure to meet overly optimistic investment return targets, and other factors, state and local government pension systems are now $1.5 trillion in debt.

title: Skip the Dude Ranch. Try a Hands-On Vacation at These Working Ranches.
summary: The pandemic made sloths of many of us. To shake off the inertia-and really get your heart pumping-book a vacation to a working cattle ranch and prepare to pitch in.. ON A RECENT Thursday at Chico Basin, an 87,000-acre cattle ranch near Colorado Springs, Colo., I sat secure in my saddle atop a palomino horse named Butters, staring down on organized chaos. Dozens of heifers and calves passed by in a stream of horns, pounding hooves and glossy, reddish backs. They were following the lead of a big, jet-black cow, christened the Widowmaker, as we herded her to a mid-pasture pen. When she suddenly darted off toward open range, Butters and I sprinted to block her escape, then ran to help deter other cows trying to run past the pen gate.

title: Gruyère, Feta and Nasturtium Soufflés
summary: This soufflé contains a trio of strong, salty cheeses. It's a delicate balance between adding enough cheese for flavor but not so much that the delicate whipped egg whites are weighed down.. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Crème Fraîche Whipped Cream
summary: While the soufflés bake, whip up this tangy cream topping. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Runner Under Doping Ban Won't Compete in U.S. Olympic Trials
summary: Shelby Houlihan, who blamed a failed drug test on a tainted burrito, won't compete, a U.S. track official confirmed. Shelby Houlihan will not compete in the U.S. Olympic track and field trials after all.

title: Luscious Lemon Soufflé Saucy Pudding
summary: Hidden underneath the puffy, heavenly, cloudlike soufflé is a luscious lemon sauce. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: The Hardest Thing at the U.S. Open: The Flagsticks
summary: A series of shots at Torrey Pines have sharply ricocheted off the pins. Why? It may have to do with the different flagsticks used at the U.S. Open.. SAN DIEGO-After Phil Mickelson fired his second shot far left into the bushes on the par-5, 613-yard 13th hole at Torrey Pines on Thursday, he took a drop and stood beneath a tree as he took dead aim at the hole. His shot was too on target.

title: Simple Soufflé Recipes: Seize the Moment
summary: It's time to start living in the now. And what better way than with a fluffy, fleeting soufflé? Whether the recipe is sweet or savory, follow a few basic tips and your results will rise above anything you can get in a restaurant.. STICK WITH ME. I'll get to the soufflés. I've been thinking about a scene in "Mad Men" where the lead character, Don Draper, goes to watch his daughter in a school maypole performance. I'm not sure whether it was in the script or an actor's choice, but the next moments capture desire and longing so evocatively. When Don (Jon Hamm) becomes aware of the beautiful, barefoot teacher dancing with her students, his gaze remains fixed on her. Suited up and hidden behind aviator sunglasses, Don imperceptibly reaches to caress the grass beneath his chair.

title: Millions of Americans Have Moved On From the Capitol Riot
summary: Peggy Noonan's barely disguised politicized dwelling on Jan. 6 serves only to exacerbate an issue which the majority of Americans have processed and are done with.. Regarding Peggy Noonan's "Why We Can't Move On From Jan. 6" (Declarations, June 12): Most of the country outside of Washington and New York moved on months ago. It isn't that those events weren't significant, but her barely disguised politicized dwelling on them serves only to exacerbate an issue which the majority of Americans have processed and are done with.

title: Good Court Behavior Begets Responsibility
summary: I have witnessed a variety of court demeanors and sportsmanship.. Regarding Tunku Varadarajan's review of "Seeing Serena" by Gerald Marzorati (Books, June 12): I focused on the point about Ms. Williams's court behavior: "It was a display that set an ugly example to every child watching the game on TV-many of whom, no doubt idolized her." As a competing amateur tennis player most of my adult life I have witnessed a variety of court demeanors and sportsmanship. More important, I was involved in an organization that worked with a summer program for junior players using a team format. Over a period of several decades, we coached over 10,000 youth in this program. Those of us involved witnessed the court behavior of the young players influenced during the John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors era.

title: Southern Baptists Should Stick to the Gospel
summary: Jesus recognized only two classes of people-saved or unsaved. He didn't consider male/female, slave/free, Jew/Gentile.. Regarding "Southern Baptists Clash Over Future" (Page One, June 12): The Southern Baptist Convention (SBC) got off track some years ago when it overlooked a time-tested truism: Jesus recognized only two classes of people-saved or unsaved. He didn't consider male/female, slave/free, Jew/Gentile. Had Jesus focused on the social issues and activism of the day, the truth of the Gospel would never have been fully known and wouldn't have spread throughout the world.

title: Shame if U.S. Abandons Afghan Translators
summary: The Afghan translators and others who helped the Americans are in mortal danger now and will probably be hunted down and murdered as soon as the American troops are gone.. Regarding your editorial "Leaving Afghan Allies Behind" (June 15): How is it the Biden administration can allow untold thousands (William McGurn reports 180,034 last month in "Stop Blaming Kamala Harris," Main Street, also June 15) of unknown and undocumented aliens to flow across the southern border of the U.S., while abandoning the thousands of Afghans who actually helped the U.S. during the war in Afghanistan? No doubt some people crossing our southern border would be in mortal danger in their home country, but most are merely looking for the better life they see in America. The Afghan translators and others who helped Americans are in mortal danger now and will probably be hunted down and murdered as soon as U.S. troops are gone.

title: Behind Migrant Families' Decisions to Separate at the Border: 'The Girl Has a Future'
summary: Resume Subscription. DIOS CON NOSOTROS, Honduras-Sayda and Maikol Zelaya knew 9-month-old Jeferson was too young to make the journey north. The parents worried the trip might be too hard on their two daughters, ages 5 and 2. That left Jordi, their rambunctious 4-year-old, always begging to go out fishing with his dad.

title: Fix Failing Schools, Don't Fiddle With the Boundaries
summary: You're not going to make any kid smarter or more educated by reorienting school district lines.. Regarding Derrell Bradford's "The Left Defends The Legacy Of Redlining" (op-ed, June 14): You're not going to make any kid smarter or more educated by reorienting school district lines. Minority kids can learn and achieve-charter schools have proved that over and over. If you have a failing school, the answer isn't to change the boundaries of the school district but to change the school itself. Fix the problem, don't hand it off.

title: Rock and Soul Mainstay Steve Cropper Is Still Making Music
summary: The guitarist and songwriter who collaborated with Otis Redding and John Lennon is releasing a new album at age 79. Steve Cropper has been the cornerstone of some of the best rock and soul music of the 20th century, revered by fellow musicians but never as well known as some of his collaborators. As guitarist, songwriter and producer, the 79-year-old Mr. Cropper made music with Otis Redding, John Lennon, Ringo Starr, Levon Helm, Jeff Beck, John Prine, the Staples Singers, Rod Stewart and Neil Young. Among the songs he helped create are "In the Midnight Hour," "(Sitting on) The Dock of the Bay," "Born Under a Bad Sign" and Booker T. and the MGs' "Green Onions," one of the most iconic instrumental tracks ever recorded.

title: Consolidation May Be Coming to a Screen Near You
summary: Meme cash lets AMC go 'on the offensive' while other chains are shopping, but final impact unclear. Far from killing the movie-exhibition industry, the pandemic may end up helping the big theater chains get even bigger.

title: HSBC to Take $3 Billion in Losses on Sale of Troubled French Bank
summary: Lender controlled by private-equity firm Cerberus will buy HSBC's French retail operations for a symbolic one euro. HSBC Holdings PLC expects to take $3 billion in losses as part of an agreement to sell its unprofitable French retail bank, in a sign of the souring fortunes of European banking.

title: At Olympic Swim Trials, the Battle Is in the Warm-Up Pool
summary: Resume Subscription. OMAHA, Neb.-Last month, Mariah Denigan graduated from high school in Kentucky. This week she's here competing in the U.S. Olympic Swim Trials against swimmers she has idolized most of her life for a spot on Team USA. But no one gets a chance at their Olympic dreams if they don't survive the warm-up pool first.

title: The Boy Who Learned to See-and What He Teaches Us About Vision
summary: Resume Subscription. To ask a blind person to acquire the sense of sight after childhood is to ask them to reshape their identity. They may have functioned quite independently when blind but now find themselves as vulnerable as a young child. With their new sight, they can see but cannot recognize a flight of stairs or a loved one's face. Bombarded by visual stimuli they don't understand, many who gain sight in adulthood become despondent, reject their vision or even lose the will to live.

title: Fiction: 'The Netanyahus' Review
summary: Joshua Cohen's novel finds a beleaguered professor managing some demanding guests.. It's a mixed blessing for a novelist when a work of fiction happens to synchronize with a major news event-if the book enjoys a sales bump it's also likelier to dissatisfy readers, who arrive expecting the more direct treatment of journalism. So while Joshua Cohen could not know that his latest novel, "The Netanyahus" (NYRB, 237 pages, $16.95), would be published the very week that Benjamin Netanyahu was ousted as prime minister of Israel after 12 consecutive years in power, he must have foreseen the danger of topicality when he gave his book its sardonic subtitle: "An Account of a Minor and Ultimately Even Negligible Episode in the History of a Very Famous Family."

title: Capital Gains: A Century-Old Tax Break Gets a Rush of Attention
summary: The Biden administration wants to raise tax rates on investment profits for the highest earners. Some Americans who aren't in the top tier would be affected as well.. Suddenly, capital-gains taxes are all over the news.

title: 'No Compromise' Review: The First Woman of Modern Design
summary: Florence Knoll brought architecture inside and changed the workplace forever.. They're loud, distracting germ factories. They prevent privacy and rarely provide personal space. Open-plan offices-the kind without physical barriers between workstations-have in recent years become both omnipresent and widely reviled. Yet the layout is anything but new. Open-plan offices were popular back in the 1950s, only they were far worse. While executives worked in wood-paneled offices with windowed views, everyone else sat in the office's core, packed into tight rows of identical tanker desks. (If you think today's setup is distracting, imagine being trapped in a pen of clacking typewriters.)

title: Wishful Thinking in a World Without Yield
summary: The need for higher returns can breed desperation for anyone with a portfolio-large or small. At first glance, the Pennsylvania Public School Employees' Retirement System, one of the largest pension plans in the U.S., doesn't sound anything like you or me. It commands $66 billion in net assets, spent $515 million last year on management fees, and has more than 40% of its net assets in exclusive investments like buyout, venture-capital and hedge funds.

title: 'Undreamed Shores' Review: The Women Who Changed Anthropology
summary: Taking on physical risk and arduous journeys, female researchers found their biggest obstacles were the attitudes of male colleagues.. Five hundred miles north of the Arctic Circle, in a bitter winter gale, a team of reindeer collapsed with exhaustion on the Siberian tundra. It was midwinter 1914. The sun had not risen for weeks; the air was hazy with diamond-hard snow. A furclad figure pulled her numb legs out of a buckskin bag, then struggled to get off her wooden sled as her guide admitted they were lost. Chilled and starving, Maria Czaplicka fantasized about killing one of the reindeer so that she could drink its warm, nourishing blood. She wondered if there was any hope of achieving her goal: to make contact with the Tungu people, known today as Evenks-nomadic reindeer-herders who had never met a European woman.

title: Swiss Scientist Refined Technology Used in MRI Scans
summary: Richard Ernst, who has died at age 87, won a Nobel prize for work that is vital to medical diagnostics and pharmaceutical research. Richard Ernst's parents worried about him. By age 3, he still wasn't talking intelligibly in the Swiss German dialect spoken at the family home in Winterthur, Switzerland.

title: Credit Suisse Cuts Business With SoftBank and Masayoshi Son
summary: Swiss bank was one of the Japanese businessman's biggest personal lenders, but stock-based loans were liquidated in the recent months, according to filings. Credit Suisse Group AG and SoftBank Group Corp. Chief Executive Masayoshi Son recently dissolved a longstanding personal lending relationship and the bank clamped down on transactions with his company, according to regulatory filings and people familiar with the matter.

title: HUD Aims to Boost Homeownership for Buyers With High Student Loans
summary: Relaxed student-debt calculation will likely qualify more Black and Hispanic buyers for federal government-backed loans. WASHINGTON-The Federal Housing Administration is relaxing the way it assesses student-loan debt when weighing eligibility for homebuying assistance as the Biden administration pushes to help lower-income borrowers and narrow a racial gap in homeownership.

title: Mysteries: 'Dream Girl' Review
summary: 'Your character seems so real' might be the ultimate compliment for a novelist-or a perfect nightmare.. Gerald Andersen, the 61-year-old writer at the heart of Laura Lippman's psychological thriller "Dream Girl" (Morrow, 310 pages, $28.99), has earned a rare and enviable success. Years ago, he published a novel, also named "Dream Girl," that "ticked all the boxes and achieved that rare literary grand slam of prestige, sales, film rights, and zeitgeist." Its perpetual royalties have bought him a duplex apartment in an ultra-modern building in his native Baltimore, as well as the freedom to live as he chooses (single, now, after three wives) and write only what he wants.

title: Relax on Father's Day? No Thanks. Give Me Madness.
summary: A holiday offers time for peaceful reflection-or just a food fight with the kids. Father's Day is nearly here, and these two children who live in my home keep asking me what I would like to do for the holiday, because, apparently, I am their father. That's what they're saying, at least. They have offered to serve me breakfast in bed, "a day of relaxation," as if two small children are constitutionally capable of offering that, and they've even asked me if I'd like a "special gift."

title: Five Best: Books on Berlin in History
summary: Selected by Barney White-Spunner, the author, most recently, of 'Berlin: The Story of a City.'. By Christopher Isherwood (1945)

title: Supreme Court Ruling on Obamacare Emboldens Democrats
summary: In courts and Congress, Republicans face a difficult path to repeal Affordable Care Act; Democrats hope to expand it further. Republicans said their effort to rein in the Affordable Care Act would be more difficult following the Supreme Court's rejection of the latest challenge to the 2010 healthcare law, as Democrats sought to expand it further.

title: Adobe, Smith & Wesson, Orphazyme: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Futures were sinking to close out a rocky week. U.S. stock futures ticked lower, putting the Dow on track for its worst weekly performance since the end of January. Here's what we're watching ahead of Friday's trading action.

title: Children's Books: Enchantments From All Over
summary: In the world of Chirri & Chirra, a little rain can't stop the magic.. The arrival of a new "Chirri & Chirra" book is always a treat for those of us fond of deliciously illustrated tableaux in the books we read with children. Through six previous adventures, Kaya Doi's pink-cheeked, bob-haired characters have traveled by bicycle under the ground, under the sea and through the seasons, and now they're off on a damp and magical escapade in "Chirri & Chirra: The Rainy Day" (Enchanted Lion, 32 pages, $16.95), translated from the Japanese by David Boyd.

title: Air Travel Returned. So Did Long Lines at Security, Restaurants and Shops.
summary: Phone holds for assistance can take hours and airports are overwhelmed. Air travel has come roaring back. Not everyone was ready.

title: Kim Jong Un Signals Willingness to Resume Nuclear Talks
summary: At a meeting of the ruling Workers' Party, leader says the country should prepare for diplomacy and confrontation with U.S.. SEOUL-Kim Jong Un said his country will prepare for both diplomacy and confrontation with the U.S., the North Korean leader's first public remarks signaling a willingness to resume nuclear negotiations since President Biden took office.

title: West Risks Blackouts as Hydroelectric Power Dries Up
summary: Heat waves across the West are already straining electricity supplies, as severe drought crimps hydroelectric power generation. States across the West are at risk of electricity shortages this summer as a crippling drought reduces the amount of water available to generate hydroelectric power.

title: Stanley Black & Decker CFO Looking for Partnerships With Battery, Chip Makers
summary: Tool maker is spending more time and money on relationship building with suppliers. Stanley Black & Decker Inc.'s finance chief is spending more time and money trying to strike partnerships with battery and chip manufacturers to help ease the pressure on the tool maker's supply chain.

title: Energy Department Seeks to Keep Grant-Backed Tech Jobs in U.S.
summary: New regulations would remove exemptions used to send manufacturing overseas. The Biden administration is moving to end exemptions that allowed technology developed with U.S. government research funding to be exported for manufacturing overseas, Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm said in an interview.

title: The World's Best Player Without a Position
summary: France midfielder N'Golo Kanté has defied soccer orthodoxy to become one of the most influential players in the game. SURESNES, France-In the days before French midfielder N'Golo Kanté dominated World Cup matches and Champions League finals, his youth coach would drive him around the Paris suburbs trying to show off a subtle, yet crucial point about his game.

title: Indonesia Faces Rising Covid-19 Cases, Dominated by Delta Variant
summary: A wave of infections like the one that hit India is feared, as parts of Indonesia explode with new cases and hospitalizations. SINGAPORE-As Covid-19 cases rise sharply in parts of Indonesia, authorities have found the highly contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus to be dominant in areas including the capital, Jakarta.

title: How Green Was My Tesla-and How Cheap?
summary: Car makers are increasingly focusing on the environmental impact of making EVs. While necessary, such efforts could slow the technology's adoption.. Auto makers need to ensure their electric vehicles are actually green. They also desperately need to bring down their cost. Pursuing both goals at once is hard.

title: Peloton Analyst Trades Endorphins for Anxiety
summary: Company's fortune favors the fundamentals rather than the bold, according to an analyst. They say all things come to those who wait, but Peloton Interactive 's investors aren't a patient bunch.

title: Compass Agents Could Get Lost
summary: Real estate broker Compass's tech-stock narrative needs all its agents to sell it. Compass says its real-estate agents come to the company for the technology. We may soon see about that.

title: Hospital Chain Got Help From Landlord as Losses Mounted
summary: Medical Properties Trust helps private-equity firms profit from hospital deals, but it is heavily exposed to financial issues at Steward Health Care. Medical Properties Trust Inc. is a little-known real-estate investor that helps private-equity firms cash in on their hospital investments. Recent financial documents provide fresh details on the close relationship and deal-making between the firm and its biggest tenant.

title: As Boy Scouts Near Civil Settlement, Criminal Probe Looms
summary: Michigan Attorney General Dana Nessel opened a criminal investigation into the sex-abuse scandal this month. After sex-abuse litigation pushed the Boy Scouts of America into bankruptcy last year, Michigan's attorney general watched as the number of victims stepping forward climbed to 84,000, dwarfing similar allegations against the Catholic Church.

title: The Skies Are Darkening for Emerging-Market Stocks
summary: With rising interest rates in some developing economies, pressure on Chinese tech and the potential for a stronger dollar, it is becoming harder to make a positive case for EM stocks. After a strong start to the year, emerging-market stocks have mostly traded sideways in recent months. There are plenty of reasons to expect their struggles to linger.

title: After Antiracism Protests, Britain's Statues Stay Put
summary: Resume Subscription. LONDON-When the Black Lives Matter movement took off last year, campaigners in Britain pushed for the removal of a statue of one of Britain's most powerful imperialists, Cecil Rhodes, that sits on the facade of Oriel College at the University of Oxford. The local council, the college itself and protesters rallied round the call that "Rhodes Must Fall."

title: China Weighs Lifting Birth Restrictions Completely by 2025
summary: Concerned about falling birthrates, policy makers plan further shift toward policies that explicitly encourage childbirth. SINGAPORE-Chinese officials are drawing up plans to further loosen birth restrictions and transition toward policies that explicitly encourage childbirth, according to people familiar with the matter, reflecting increased urgency in Beijing as economic growth slows and China's population mix skews older.

title: Hong Kong Police Arrest Apple Daily Editor Under China National Security Law
summary: Journalist groups fear for press freedoms as police raid newsroom of jailed tycoon Jimmy Lai's newspaper and city's security chief issues warning to supporters. HONG KONG-Authorities sent shudders through Hong Kong media outlets after police arrested the top editor of a popular daily newspaper and the city's security chief warned of severe punishment for anyone who uses news to challenge China's national security.

title: CVS and Walgreens Were Reeling From Pandemic, but Fortunes Have Changed
summary: After struggling early in the pandemic, pharmacy chains say vaccines have been a boon to business. As the Covid-19 pandemic bore down last spring, America's drugstore giants warned investors that the health crisis threatened their already tenuous turnarounds.

title: Europe's Chief Prosecutor Has 300 Cases on Her Plate Already
summary: Laura Codruta Kövesi, head of the brand-new European Public Prosecutor's Office, wants to hire 50 more investigators. The European Union this month launched a regionwide prosecutor's office to investigate crimes such as corruption, value-added tax fraud and the misuse of Covid-19 recovery funds.

title: Funding for Bezos Space Company Fails to Launch in House
summary: Members from both parties made clear the Senate's $10 billion authorization was a nonstarter. HOUSE THROWS UP ROADBLOCKS to funding for Jeff Bezos's Blue Origin space exploration company that was approved as part of the Senate's bipartisan China competition legislation last week. Members from both parties made clear the $10 billion authorization, pushed by Washington Democratic Sen. Maria Cantwell, for a second moon lander contract (Elon Musk's SpaceX won the first contract earlier this year, while Blue Origin was one of two runners-up) was a nonstarter for the House's version of science and innovation legislation.

title: Lawmakers Urge Private Sector to Do More on Cybersecurity
summary: String of cyberattacks shows need for companies to 'step up,' politicians say. The private sector in the U.S. must do more to defend against cyberattacks, lawmakers from both major parties stressed Thursday as several senators introduced legislation designed to target hackers.

title: It Isn't Just AMC. Retail Traders Increase Pull on the Stock Market.
summary: Data shows amateur investors have been upending everything from trading volume to large investors' bets. Call it the year of the individual investor.

title: Venture Capital's New Bet: Black Entrepreneurs
summary: Funds increasingly seek out diversity among company founders. Austin Clements was ready to give up.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Fiction: 'The Netanyahus' Review
summary: Joshua Cohen's novel finds a beleaguered professor managing some demanding guests.. It's a mixed blessing for a novelist when a work of fiction happens to synchronize with a major news event-if the book enjoys a sales bump it's also likelier to dissatisfy readers, who arrive expecting the more direct treatment of journalism. So while Joshua Cohen could not know that his latest novel, "The Netanyahus" (NYRB, 237 pages, $16.95), would be published the very week that Benjamin Netanyahu was ousted as prime minister of Israel after 12 consecutive years in power, he must have foreseen the danger of topicality when he gave his book its sardonic subtitle: "An Account of a Minor and Ultimately Even Negligible Episode in the History of a Very Famous Family."

title: Turkey Commits to Securing Kabul Airport After U.S. Troops Leave
summary: A major source of strain between the nations, Ankara's purchase of a Russian air defense system, remains unresolved. WASHINGTON-The U.S. and Turkey have agreed to a plan for the Turks to continue providing security at the airport in Kabul, U.S. officials said, ensuring the U.S. and other nations can maintain a diplomatic presence in Afghanistan following the withdrawal of troops, expected by next month.

title: Tali Farhadian Weinstein Spends Big in Manhattan District Attorney Race
summary: The candidate has donated over $8 million of her own money to fund a television and social-media advertising blitz rarely seen in a prosecutor election. Manhattan district attorney candidate Tali Farhadian Weinstein is buying television and social-media advertising with millions of dollars of her own money, a spending spree in the final days before Tuesday's primary that observers say is rare for a prosecutor election.
